rsbNotes.title: Isa 40–55
rsbNotes.text: 40:1–55:13 Isaiah originally addressed these words to the future exiles in Babylon to encourage them to flee from there and return by faith to the Promised Land (e.g., 48:20, 21). The encouragement partially arises from their supernatural character (e.g., 41:21–27). These prophecies, delivered more than a century and a half beforehand (see Introduction: Interpretive Difficulties), astonish their audience by predicting Israel’s (i.e., Judah’s) immediate deliverance from Babylon by Cyrus (e.g., 44:24–45:13), the coming of the suffering Christ to save them from their sins after they return to the land (42:1–7; 49:1–13; 50:4–11; 52:13–53:12), and Israel’s final salvation in the last days (51:6). The near, more remote, and most remote prophecies merge together on the canvas. From Isaiah’s perspective, the restoration after the Exile inaugurates the new age, and this first taste of salvation through God’s servant, Cyrus, coalesces with the greater salvation that the Christ, God’s servant, will bring His people. Today, the elect have even more confidence in words of prophecy because these have been fulfilled in Christ and are being fulfilled in His Church (2 Pet. 1:19).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:14
rsbNotes.text: 43:14 Redeemer. See 35:9; 41:14 and notes.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:16
rsbNotes.text: 43:16 sea . . . mighty waters. Isaiah refers to the crossing of the Red Sea (Ex. 14; 15).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:17
rsbNotes.text: 43:17 chariot and horse, army and warrior. The prophet recalls the chariots of Egypt that were destroyed before the face of the Lord (cf. 31:1).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:19
rsbNotes.text:
43:19 new thing. The exodus from Egypt is less important than the new era of redemption (42:9 note).

wilderness . . . desert. See note 40:3.

rivers. See note 41:18.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:20
rsbNotes.text:
43:20 beasts . . . ostriches. These creatures are associated with desolate areas (34:11–15). See note 13:20–22.

water. This recalls God’s provision in the wilderness (Ex. 15:22–26). See note 1:30.

my chosen people. See notes on vv. 1, 3.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:22
rsbNotes.text: 43:22 not call . . . been weary. Instead of presenting offerings and sacrifices, the people were hardened in their sins.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:23
rsbNotes.text: 43:23 have not brought me your sheep. The people followed more than one religious practice, but these were not necessarily offered to God. On the emptiness of sacrifices which are mere external rituals, see Jer. 7:21–23 note.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:24
rsbNotes.text: 43:24 sweet cane. An aromatic plant, possibly sugar cane.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:25
rsbNotes.text:
43:25 I, I am he. A repetition for emphasis.

blots . . . remember. God forgives sin, as Israel had experienced after the incident of the golden calf (Ex. 34:6, 7; cf. Luke 5:21). The Lord graciously promises to forgive and to establish His word (37:35; 42:21; 48:9, 11).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:26
rsbNotes.text: 43:26 set forth your case. They stood condemned, unable to refute God’s charge.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:27
rsbNotes.text:
43:27 first father. Jacob was the father of the twelve tribes (Hos. 12:2, 3).

mediators. These are the religious leaders, including prophets and priests.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 43:28
rsbNotes.text: 43:28 princes . . . reviling. Judah was disgraced by the destruction of the temple and the exile of her people (63:18; cf. 2 Kin. 25:18–21).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:1
rsbNotes.text:
44:1 servant. See notes 20:3; 41:8; 42:1.

chosen. See notes 14:1; 43:3.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:2
rsbNotes.text:
44:2 formed. See note 27:11.

from the womb. God likens Himself to a mother who has conceived and will give birth (v. 24; 42:14; 66:9).

Fear not. See notes 10:24; 35:4.

Jeshurun. A poetic name for Israel (Deut. 32:15), meaning “upright one.”

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:3
rsbNotes.text:
44:3 pour my Spirit . . . offspring. This passage develops the promises in 28:6; 32:15. The Spirit lives in the children of the covenant today (Joel 2:28, 29; Acts 2:38, 39).

blessing. The Spirit will also confirm God’s promises. For the connection between water and the Spirit see Mark 1:8–10.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:5
rsbNotes.text: 44:5 This one . . . another. Many will participate in the new age of restoration, as Gentiles and Jews together will confess the name of the Lord (cf. Ps. 87:4–6).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:6–20
rsbNotes.text: 44:6–20 The Lord confronts the idols. On Isaiah’s polemic against idolatry (vv. 9–20), see 2:8 note.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:6
rsbNotes.text:
44:6 See theological note “One and Three: The Trinity.”

Redeemer. See note 35:9, 10.

first . . . last. See note 41:4.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:8
rsbNotes.text: 44:8 Rock. See 8:14, 15 note; Deut. 32:4, 15, 31.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:9
rsbNotes.text:
44:9 nothing . . . not profit. See 41:29 note.

Their witnesses. The “witnesses” could be the idols or their makers. Neither has any power of sight or understanding (Ps. 115:8).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:11
rsbNotes.text: 44:11 assemble . . . stand. The setting is a court of law (41:21).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:12
rsbNotes.text: 44:12 An idol may be a work of art. But even the finest craftsman’s mortality is revealed in his hunger and thirst. In contrast, see 40:28.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:13
rsbNotes.text: 44:13 figure of a man. The carpenter makes his god in his own image (Deut. 4:16; Rom. 1:22, 23).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:18
rsbNotes.text: 44:18 know . . . discern. They are utterly foolish (v. 9; 6:9, 10).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:19
rsbNotes.text: 44:19 an abomination . . . block of wood. The prophet employs ridicule to expose the foolishness of idolatry. See “Mankind’s Guilty Knowledge of God” at Rom. 1:19.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:20
rsbNotes.text: 44:20 lie. The conclusion: idolatry is a deception, a hoax.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:22
rsbNotes.text: 44:22 redeemed. The Lord alone is the Redeemer (35:9, 10; 41:14 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:23
rsbNotes.text:
44:23 heavens . . . every tree. All creation will praise God for His salvation of Israel.

glorified. God will glorify the redeemed, who in turn will lead many to praise the Lord for His mighty acts (4:2 note; 49:3; 55:5; 60:21; 61:3).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:25
rsbNotes.text: 44:25 diviners. Divination was strictly forbidden in Israel (2:6; 8:19 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:26
rsbNotes.text:
44:26 word . . . counsel. These refer to the Lord’s revelations of His plan (11:2 note).

servant. See notes 20:3; 41:8; 42:1.

ruins. These are the regions devastated by Babylon. The restoration of Judah was the beginning of a new stage in the history of redemption.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:27
rsbNotes.text: 44:27 deep . . . rivers. Possibly a reference to the crossing of the Red Sea (43:16, 19 and notes). The prophecy may have found a literal fulfillment when Cyrus diverted the water of the Euphrates River and marched his army through the gates that allowed it to flow through the city of Babylon (45:2 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 44:28
rsbNotes.text:
44:28 my shepherd. Kings were often called shepherds (2 Sam. 5:2; Jer. 3:15; cf. Mic. 5:4). Cyrus ruled by God’s decree.

Jerusalem . . . temple. These were rebuilt by Cyrus’s royal decree (Ezra 1:2–4; 6:3–5).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 45:1
rsbNotes.text:
45:1 his anointed. This title is not used elsewhere of anyone outside Israel, and its application to Cyrus would have shocked Isaiah’s audience.

right hand I have grasped. He rules by Yahweh’s authority (41:2; 48:14; cf. Ps. 2:8, 9; 110:1).

nations . . . kings. See note 41:2.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 45:2
rsbNotes.text:
45:2 break . . . cut. Nothing can withstand the Lord’s servant (cf. Ps. 107:16).

doors. The prophecy may have had a literal fulfillment when Cyrus used the gates that allowed the Euphrates to flow through Babylon (44:27 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 45:3
rsbNotes.text:
45:3 darkness . . . secret places. Precious metals came from deep mines (Job 28:1–6). Cyrus plundered the fabulous wealth of Lydia in 546 b.c.

call you by your name. The Lord has raised up Cyrus and knows him (compare 43:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 45:4
rsbNotes.text:
45:4 servant. See notes at 20:3; 41:8; 42:1.

chosen. See note 14:1.

name you. As God’s “shepherd” (44:28) and “anointed” (v. 1), Cyrus has a title of honor.

you do not know me. Cyrus remained an unbeliever.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 45:7
rsbNotes.text:
45:7 form. See note 27:11.

light . . . darkness. The Lord asserts His power over two fundamental poles of reality, as described in Gen. 1:3, 4. The parallel terms “well-being” and “calamity” include the political realities that Cyrus was going to disturb in fulfilling the counsel of God.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 45:8
rsbNotes.text: 45:8 heavens . . . earth. Creation must prepare itself for the Lord’s act of redemption, described by two synonyms: “righteousness” and “salvation” (12:2; 26:17, 18 and notes).
